POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of the Mathematical Sciences Research Postdoctoral Fellowhip is to facilitate participation of the principal investigator (PI) in a postdoctoral research environment that will have maximal impact on their future scientific development. In this case the PI carried out his fellowship activities at the mathematics department of the University of Texas-Austin, under the supervision of Professor Alan Reid. During tenure, the PI developed a rich research program, improving upon the initial results from his Ph.D. thesis and also initiating several new directions. The mathematical research conducted belongs to a subject called geometric topology which studies geometric manifolds, abstract mathematical objects designed to model the world we live in. The PI carefully studied several special types of geometric manifolds, called hyperbolic manifolds and anti de Sitter (AdS) manifolds. The former are Riemannian manifolds of constant negative curvature which play the central role in the topological classification of three-dimensional manifolds. The latter are Lorentzian manifolds of constant negative curvature which serve as basic models for relativistic spacetime in physics. The main goal of the proposal was to study connections between these two types of geometric manifolds using a mathematical mechanism called geometric transition. Despite the differences between the two geometries, there is a natural process, discovered by the PI in his Ph.D. thesis, by which one may continuously tranform into the other. During tenure, the PI developed further the theory of geometric transitions in this and several other related settings. The PI also developed several interesting mathematical applications. In a newly formed collaboration with Sara Maloni and Jean-Marc Schlenker, the PI discovered a new classification result, joint with S. Maloni and Jean-Marc Schlenker, about convex ideal polyhedra in anti de Sitter space, following I. Rivin's celebrated result on ideal polyhedra in hyperbolic space. The result, which is of independent interest in the classical subject of combinatorics of Euclidean polyhedra, may be interpretted as an initial step towards Mess's bending conjecture in AdS geometry, one of the motivating goals of this proposal. The PI also began a new project, joint with Francois Gueritaud and Fanny Kassel, to study certain complete flat Lorentzian spacetimes in dimension three, called Margulis spacetimes, as limits of complete anti de Sitter spacetimes. This project utilized some of the geometric transition tools described in the project proposal, developing them in the new setting of the the transition from curved Lorentzian geometry to flat Lorentzian geometry. This new point of view led to the resolution of the topological tameness conjecture for Margulis spacetimes, posed by Drumm and Goldman in 1995. Further, the PI and collaborators were able to parameterize the moduli space of Margulis spacetimes, giving a simple combinatorial method for constructing every such spacetime.
